categories.name: Pain & Fever Management
categories.description: Analgesic and antipyretic medicines that reduce pain and fever across common illnesses.

medicines.use: General pain relief and reduction of fever.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Preferred first-line for mild to moderate pain and fever because of its strong safety profile when dosed correctly.
medicines.patientGuidance: Maintain at least 4-hour intervals between doses and avoid taking with other paracetamol-containing products.

medicines.use: Pain relief and fever reduction.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Offers quick relief for fever spikes and musculoskeletal pain episodes.
medicines.patientGuidance: Swallow with water after food if the stomach is sensitive; monitor total daily dose (max 4 g for adults).

medicines.use: Pain relief and fever reduction.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Extended-release option helps maintain steady fever control, particularly overnight.
medicines.patientGuidance: Do not crush extended-release tablets; take whole with water.

medicines.use: NSAID for pain, inflammation, and fever.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Chosen when inflammation or muscle injury is suspected along with pain.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with food to reduce stomach irritation; avoid if you have kidney issues or gastric ulcers.

medicines.use: Short-term management of moderate to severe acute pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Used when pain is not controlled by weaker NSAIDs, typically for short courses post-surgery or injury.
medicines.patientGuidance: Limit use to ≤5 days due to bleeding and kidney risks; avoid combining with other NSAIDs.

medicines.use: NSAID for musculoskeletal pain, inflammation, and post-operative discomfort.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Multiple dosage forms allow flexible titration and targeted relief when oral intake is limited.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take tablets after meals with water, apply gel only on intact skin, and reserve injections for clinician supervision.

medicines.use: Once-daily anti-inflammatory coverage for chronic arthritis and soft tissue pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Sustained-release formulation maintains steadier plasma levels and improves adherence in long-term therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Swallow whole after food, do not crush or split, and monitor for stomach pain or indigestion.

medicines.use: Fast-acting NSAID for acute musculoskeletal and dental pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Potassium salt dissolves quickly, offering a faster onset of analgesia than standard diclofenac sodium tablets.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with food to reduce gastric irritation and avoid using alongside other NSAIDs or anticoagulants.

medicines.use: Parenteral analgesic for severe acute pain when oral therapy is not feasible.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Combines diclofenac's anti-inflammatory effect with lidocaine to minimise injection-site discomfort and provide rapid relief.
medicines.patientGuidance: Administer intramuscularly by healthcare professionals only; observe for allergic reactions or local numbness.

medicines.use: Reduces fever and relieves mild pain in children.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Palatable suspension allows weight-based pediatric dosing when tablets are inappropriate.
medicines.patientGuidance: Use the supplied measuring device, keep at least 4-hour intervals between doses, and do not exceed the recommended daily amount.

medicines.use: Relieves tension headaches, migraine attacks, and fatigue-associated pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Caffeine enhances paracetamol's analgesic effect and counteracts drowsiness, improving relief in refractory headaches.
medicines.patientGuidance: Limit total daily paracetamol intake, avoid late-evening doses due to caffeine, and monitor for palpitations.

medicines.use: Provides prolonged relief from chronic pain or persistent fever episodes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Extended-release matrix delivers paracetamol over 6–8 hours, reducing dosing frequency in chronic conditions.
medicines.patientGuidance: Swallow whole without crushing, maintain dosing intervals, and track cumulative paracetamol from all sources.

medicines.use: NSAID for osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Aceclofenac offers potent anti-inflammatory action with comparatively favourable gastrointestinal tolerability.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take after meals, avoid concurrent NSAIDs, and report persistent stomach upsets or swelling.

medicines.use: Once-daily regimen for sustained control of chronic inflammatory pain.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Sustained-release formulation maintains therapeutic levels across the day, enhancing adherence for long-term therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Swallow whole with water, do not break or chew, and monitor for signs of fluid retention or gastrointestinal bleeding.

medicines.use: Relieves pain and swelling associated with osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and musculoskeletal injury.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Provides potent COX-2 selective anti-inflammatory activity with a tolerable GI profile for chronic use when other NSAIDs are unsuitable.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take after meals with water, avoid combining with other NSAIDs, and report indigestion, black stool, or edema promptly.

categories.name: Gastric & Digestive Health
categories.description: Medicines that reduce stomach acid, support digestion, and manage nausea or reflux.

medicines.use: Reduces stomach acid, treats GERD, ulcers, and heartburn.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Helps heal erosive esophagitis and prevents acid-related damage during chronic symptoms.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take 30 minutes before meals, preferably breakfast.

medicines.use: Reduces stomach acid and heals reflux-related damage.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative brand to maintain therapy continuity when cost or availability changes.
medicines.patientGuidance: Do not crush the tablet; complete the prescribed course even if symptoms improve early.

medicines.use: Treats indigestion, heartburn, and ulcers by reducing stomach acid.
medicines.whyPrescribed: First-line proton pump inhibitor for chronic gastritis or ulcer protection when on NSAIDs.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take before meals; long-term use should be reviewed to monitor for vitamin deficiencies.

medicines.use: Reduces stomach acid for GERD and ulcers.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Preferred when patients have better tolerance to pantoprazole or need once-daily dosing.
medicines.patientGuidance: Avoid alcohol and spicy meals that can trigger reflux.

medicines.use: Targets excessive stomach acid and GERD.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Considered when rapid acid suppression is needed or other PPIs did not respond.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take once daily; report persistent diarrhoea or stomach pain to your doctor.

medicines.use: Reduces stomach acid and supports ulcer healing.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Stable formulation for long-term maintenance therapy in chronic acid reflux.
medicines.patientGuidance: Monitor for symptom relief within 3-5 days; continue lifestyle changes (smaller meals, early dinner).

medicines.use: Reduces stomach acid for indigestion and ulcers.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative brand for affordability or supply preferences.
medicines.patientGuidance: Prefer morning dosing; avoid abrupt discontinuation after long-term use—consult doctor.

medicines.use: H2 blocker reducing stomach acid for ulcers and heartburn.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Used for nighttime acid control or when PPIs are contraindicated.
medicines.patientGuidance: Can be taken with or without food; avoid simultaneous antacid use without doctor advice.

medicines.use: Treats nausea, vomiting, and improves stomach emptying.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Helps relieve bloating and early fullness by promoting gastric motility.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take 15-30 minutes before meals; report palpitations or dizziness immediately.

medicines.use: Treats nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternate supply for prokinetic therapy to manage gastroparesis-like symptoms.
medicines.patientGuidance: Limit to short-term use unless advised; avoid with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors.

medicines.use: Provides antispasmodic relief for irritable bowel syndrome and functional abdominal cramps.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Targets smooth muscle spasm in the gut without affecting normal peristalsis, improving IBS symptom control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take 20 minutes before meals, swallow whole without chewing, and continue dietary fibre and hydration measures.

medicines.use: Bowel cleansing solution for constipation relief and colonoscopy preparation.
medicines.whyPrescribed: High-molecular-weight PEG draws water into the bowel while balanced electrolytes prevent significant fluid and electrolyte shifts.
medicines.patientGuidance: Dilute as directed, drink adequate clear fluids throughout therapy, and expect loose stools within hours.

medicines.use: Osmotic laxative for rapid relief of constipation and bowel emptying prior to diagnostic procedures.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Provides a ready-to-use PEG-electrolyte formulation suitable for patients requiring predictable catharsis, especially during colonoscopy prep.
medicines.patientGuidance: Follow the full dosing schedule, drink extra clear liquids to maintain hydration, and discontinue if severe abdominal pain occurs.

categories.name: Anti-Infectives
categories.description: Antibiotics, antifungals, and antivirals used to control infections under physician guidance.

medicines.use: Treats respiratory and urinary tract infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Effective once or twice daily dosing for susceptible bacterial infections.
medicines.patientGuidance: Complete the full course even if symptoms improve; may cause mild digestive upset.

medicines.use: Broad-spectrum antibiotic for respiratory and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Short-course therapy (typically 3-5 days) with good tissue penetration.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take on an empty stomach for better absorption; avoid antacids within 2 hours.

medicines.use: Treats respiratory, ear, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Second-generation cephalosporin for resistant organisms.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take after food to enhance absorption; report allergic reactions immediately.

medicines.use: Broad-spectrum antibiotic for upper respiratory and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative brand to maintain therapy continuity when travel or cost factors arise.
medicines.patientGuidance: Follow the exact dosing schedule to prevent resistance; stay hydrated.

medicines.use: Potent antibiotic for severe hospital infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Combination therapy covering resistant gram-negative and anaerobic bacteria.
medicines.patientGuidance: Administered in hospital; monitor for signs of allergic reaction or diarrhoea.

medicines.use: Treats urinary, respiratory, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Chosen for culture-sensitive gram-negative infections.
medicines.patientGuidance: Avoid dairy or antacids near dosing; watch for tendon pain and limit sunlight exposure.

medicines.use: Broad coverage for resistant bacterial infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Clavulanic acid protects the antibiotic from degradation by resistant bacteria.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take at meal start to reduce stomach upset; note possible diarrhoea.

medicines.use: Treats various bacterial infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative cefixime brand for continuity when availability shifts.
medicines.patientGuidance: Complete full course; keep suspension refrigerated if instructed.

medicines.use: Treats systemic and mucosal fungal infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Single-dose therapy for uncomplicated candidiasis or longer courses for systemic infection.
medicines.patientGuidance: Report rash or liver-related symptoms; avoid alcohol during therapy.

medicines.use: Narrow-spectrum penicillin for beta-lactamase producing staphylococcal infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Stable to penicillinase, making it useful against MSSA skin, soft tissue, and bone infections.
medicines.patientGuidance: Administer on an empty stomach for best absorption and complete the full prescribed course.

medicines.use: Antiparasitic therapy for strongyloidiasis, onchocerciasis, and scabies outbreaks.
medicines.whyPrescribed: High efficacy and single-dose convenience improve compliance in mass treatment campaigns.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take on an empty stomach with water and monitor for transient itching or dizziness after dosing.

medicines.use: Topical antifungal for oral thrush and denture stomatitis.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Adheres to the oral mucosa for prolonged contact, offering high local concentrations with minimal systemic exposure.
medicines.patientGuidance: Retain gel in the mouth as long as possible before swallowing and continue treatment for 2 days after symptoms resolve.

medicines.use: Macrolide antibiotic for respiratory, skin, and pertussis infections in children.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Suitable alternative for penicillin-allergic patients and offers palatable formulations for pediatric dosing.
medicines.patientGuidance: Shake well before use, measure doses carefully, and give on an empty stomach unless upset occurs.

medicines.use: Topical antibiotic for inflammatory acne lesions.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Delivers targeted antimicrobial action to reduce Propionibacterium acnes load and inflammation.
medicines.patientGuidance: Apply to clean, dry skin twice daily and avoid contact with eyes or mucous membranes.

medicines.use: Broad-spectrum ophthalmic antibiotic for bacterial conjunctivitis.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Provides rapid coverage against common ocular pathogens with minimal systemic absorption.
medicines.patientGuidance: Instil the prescribed drops into the affected eye(s), avoid touching the dropper tip, and discontinue contact lens use during treatment.

medicines.use: Combines anti-inflammatory and antibacterial action for post-operative or severe ocular infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Corticosteroid component reduces inflammation while chloramphenicol treats the underlying infection in one preparation.
medicines.patientGuidance: Use under ophthalmologist supervision, adhere to duration limits, and monitor for signs of raised intraocular pressure.

medicines.use: Macrolide antibiotic for community-acquired pneumonia, ENT, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Once-daily dosing with excellent tissue penetration offers convenient short-course therapy and high compliance.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take tablets at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after food, mix suspension with the measured water volume, and complete the full course.

medicines.use: Macrolide therapy for respiratory, skin, and pertussis infections, especially in penicillin-sensitive patients.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Provides multiple strengths for flexible dosing in adults and children requiring erythromycin.
medicines.patientGuidance: Administer on an empty stomach unless GI upset occurs; shake suspension well and store in refrigerator after reconstitution if advised.

medicines.use: Oral macrolide for pediatric respiratory and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Pleasant-tasting suspension supports adherence in children requiring erythromycin when penicillins are unsuitable.
medicines.patientGuidance: Reconstitute with boiled and cooled water, shake before each dose, and use calibrated spoons or syringes.

medicines.use: Treats susceptible respiratory and soft tissue infections in children.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative erythromycin suspension ensures supply continuity across pharmacies.
medicines.patientGuidance: Shake thoroughly prior to dosing, complete therapy as directed, and monitor for diarrhoea or rash.

medicines.use: Fluoroquinolone for community-acquired pneumonia, complicated skin, and intra-abdominal infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Once-daily broad-spectrum coverage is useful when resistance to other quinolones is suspected.
medicines.patientGuidance: Avoid antacids or supplements containing iron or magnesium within 6 hours and seek care if tendon pain or palpitations occur.

medicines.use: Macrolide antibiotic for respiratory tract infections, H. pylori eradication, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Available in oral and injectable forms, supporting step-down therapy and continuity of care.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take tablets with or without food, reconstitute suspension with measured water, and administer IV infusion under clinical supervision only.

medicines.use: Once-daily macrolide for respiratory, ENT, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Capsule and suspension presentations support adult and pediatric regimens within the same brand.
medicines.patientGuidance: Maintain consistent dosing intervals, avoid skipping doses, and store reconstituted suspension as per label.

medicines.use: Treats respiratory tract, skin, and soft tissue infections caused by susceptible organisms.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Ensures azithromycin availability with consistent local distribution networks.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take tablets on an empty stomach, mix suspension precisely, and complete the 3- or 5-day regimen even if symptoms improve.

medicines.use: Macrolide antibiotic for respiratory, genitourinary, and skin infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Convenient capsule form supports adherence in adult dosing schedules.
medicines.patientGuidance: Swallow with water at least 1 hour before meals, and monitor for diarrhoea or signs of liver dysfunction.

medicines.use: Topical antibiotic therapy for acne vulgaris lesions.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Dermatology-focused formulation reduces inflammatory lesions while minimising systemic exposure.
medicines.patientGuidance: Apply a thin layer to cleansed skin twice daily and discontinue if marked irritation or dryness occurs.

categories.name: Reproductive Health
categories.description: Medicines that support women's reproductive care, family planning, and hormonal management under clinical supervision.

medicines.use: Medical termination of early intrauterine pregnancy as part of a supervised regimen.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Combines sequential anti-progestin and prostaglandin tablets in a single pack following international protocols for medical abortion up to 9 weeks gestation.
medicines.patientGuidance: Use strictly under qualified medical guidance, confirm gestational age and exclude ectopic pregnancy, and be prepared for cramping and bleeding with emergency contact on hand.

categories.name: Oncology & Immunotherapy
categories.description: Targeted anticancer agents and monoclonal antibodies used under specialist supervision.

medicines.use: Tyrosine kinase inhibitor for chronic myeloid leukemia and Philadelphia chromosome-positive ALL.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Active against multiple BCR-ABL mutations, supporting patients who are resistant or intolerant to prior therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take at the same time daily, avoid grapefruit products, monitor for fluid retention, and report bleeding or shortness of breath immediately.

medicines.use: CD20-directed monoclonal antibody for non-Hodgkin lymphoma and rheumatoid arthritis.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Provides biosimilar access to rituximab, enabling immunochemotherapy protocols at lower cost.
medicines.patientGuidance: Infuse in hospital with premedication, monitor for infusion reactions, and adhere to infection prophylaxis as advised.

medicines.use: Monoclonal antibody indicated for lymphoma, chronic lymphocytic leukemia, and autoimmune disorders.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Reference rituximab brand with extensive clinical data for combination regimens and maintenance therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Administer in specialist centres, monitor CBC and hepatitis status, and seek urgent help for fever or breathing difficulty post infusion.

categories.name: Respiratory Health
categories.description: Medicines that assist with asthma control, mucus clearance, and cough relief.

medicines.use: Prevents asthma attacks and treats allergic rhinitis.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Helps control allergy-triggered asthma by blocking leukotrienes.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take in the evening for better asthma control; not for acute attacks.

medicines.use: Prevents asthma attacks and relieves allergic rhinitis.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative brand to maintain long-term leukotriene control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Chewable tablets should be taken before bedtime; report mood changes to your physician.

medicines.use: Prevents asthma attacks and allergic rhinitis symptoms.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Used when patients respond well to montelukast maintenance therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Continue inhaled maintenance therapy; montelukast alone doesn't replace inhalers.

medicines.use: Mucolytic that thins mucus and improves airway clearance.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Helps break down thick mucus in productive coughs.
medicines.patientGuidance: Increase water intake to support mucus thinning.

medicines.use: Loosens and clears thick bronchial mucus in productive coughs and respiratory infections.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Pleasantly flavoured syrup offers weight-based dosing for both pediatric and adult patients requiring mucolytic therapy.
medicines.patientGuidance: Measure each dose accurately, take after food to minimise gastric irritation, and maintain adequate hydration for best effect.

medicines.use: Combination syrup for cough and cold relief.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Addresses cough reflex, nasal congestion, and allergy-related symptoms simultaneously.
medicines.patientGuidance: May cause drowsiness; avoid other sedating medications and alcohol.

categories.name: Cardiovascular Health
categories.description: Medications to manage hypertension, cholesterol, and cardiac workload.

medicines.use: Treats high blood pressure and angina.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Calcium channel blocker that relaxes blood vessels for long-lasting BP control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take at the same time daily; monitor ankle swelling or dizziness.

medicines.use: Treats high blood pressure.
medicines.whyPrescribed: ARB that protects the cardiovascular system and kidneys in hypertension.
medicines.patientGuidance: Check blood pressure regularly; avoid potassium-rich salt substitutes without advice.

medicines.use: Combination therapy for high blood pressure.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Simplifies dosing when two agents are needed for BP control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take once daily; monitor for leg swelling or persistent cough.

medicines.use: Treats high blood pressure and protects kidneys in diabetes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: ARB with renal protective effects in hypertensive diabetics.
medicines.patientGuidance: Monitor kidney function and potassium levels per schedule.

medicines.use: Lowers cholesterol and cardiovascular risk.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Statin therapy to reduce LDL cholesterol and plaque buildup.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take at night; report muscle pain or dark urine immediately.

medicines.use: Lowers cholesterol and cardiovascular risk.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative atorvastatin brand for therapy continuation.
medicines.patientGuidance: Follow a heart-healthy diet alongside medication.

medicines.use: Lowers cholesterol and reduces cardiovascular risk.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Strong LDL-lowering statin for high-risk patients.
medicines.patientGuidance: May be taken at any time; maintain routine lipid profile checks.

medicines.use: Lowers cholesterol and reduces cardiovascular risk.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative rosuvastatin brand when patient preference or availability changes.
medicines.patientGuidance: Combine with diet and exercise; report unexplained muscle soreness.

medicines.use: Beta-blocker for high blood pressure, angina, and heart failure.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Reduces heart workload and helps rhythm control in cardiac conditions.
medicines.patientGuidance: Do not stop suddenly; monitor heart rate and report dizziness or fatigue.

medicines.use: Endothelin receptor antagonist for long-term management of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Oral once-daily therapy slows disease progression and reduces hospitalization when added to PAH treatment regimens.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take at the same time daily, perform periodic liver function and hemoglobin monitoring, and avoid use in pregnancy—reliable contraception required.

categories.name: Diabetes Management
categories.description: Therapies that improve insulin sensitivity or provide insulin replacement to control blood glucose.

medicines.use: Oral medication for Type 2 Diabetes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Stimulates pancreatic insulin release for better post-meal control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with breakfast; carry a sugar source to treat potential hypoglycaemia.

medicines.use: Oral medication for Type 2 Diabetes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: First-line therapy that lowers glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with meals to reduce stomach upset; monitor kidney function annually.

medicines.use: Oral medication for Type 2 Diabetes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Affordable metformin brand for continued glycaemic control.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with meals; report persistent diarrhoea or fatigue.

medicines.use: Controls blood sugar in Type 1 and Type 2 Diabetes.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Essential when pancreatic insulin is insufficient; dosing tailored to glucose patterns.
medicines.patientGuidance: Store in refrigerator; rotate injection sites and monitor for hypoglycaemia.

categories.name: Vitamins & Nutritional Supplements
categories.description: Supplements to address nutritional deficiencies and support general health.

medicines.use: Bone health and supplementation of calcium and vitamin D.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Supports bone density, especially in osteoporosis prevention.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with meals; ensure adequate hydration to prevent kidney stones.

medicines.use: Calcium and vitamin D supplementation.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Alternative brand ensuring consistent supply for chronic supplementation.
medicines.patientGuidance: Separate from iron supplements by at least 2 hours for better absorption.

medicines.use: Treats B vitamin deficiencies and supports nerve health.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Useful in neuropathy and recovery after nerve injury or chronic alcohol use.
medicines.patientGuidance: Maintain consistent daily dosing; injections may require clinic visits.

medicines.use: Vitamin C supplementation and antioxidant support.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Supports immunity and collagen synthesis during recovery.
medicines.patientGuidance: Chew thoroughly; excessive dosing may cause stomach upset.

medicines.use: Prevents and treats vitamin A deficiency and supports vision and immune function.
medicines.whyPrescribed: High-potency supplement replenishes hepatic vitamin A stores in patients at risk of deficiency.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take with meals containing fat for better absorption and avoid exceeding recommended frequency to prevent hypervitaminosis A.

medicines.use: Supports bone remineralisation and replenishes dietary calcium and vitamin D in deficiency states.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Eggshell-derived calcium provides a bioavailable mineral source while vitamin D3 enhances intestinal absorption and skeletal uptake.
medicines.patientGuidance: Take after meals with water, separate from iron supplements by 2 hours, and maintain weight-bearing exercise where possible.

medicines.use: Treats vitamin B12 deficiency-related neuropathy, anemia, and fatigue.
medicines.whyPrescribed: Neurologically active methylcobalamin form supports myelin repair and improves peripheral neuropathic symptoms more rapidly than cyanocobalamin.
medicines.patientGuidance: Allow tablet to dissolve under the tongue or swallow with water after meals and monitor blood counts during prolonged therapy.
